dataset.title: City of Seattle, Cedar River Watershed, Planting for Resilience 2011 - 2017

creator.organizationName: City of Seattle, Seattle Public Utilities
City of Seattle, Seattle Public Utilities
City of Seattle, Seattle Public Utilities

abstract.para: The resilience planting trail was designed to test adaptations of different tree species to changing environmental conditions. Select tree species and Douglas-fir from an Oregon seed zone were evaluated for their ability to grow and reproduce in glacial outwash soils in the lower Cedar River Municipal Watershed (CRMW) under conditions expected with global climate change.

Glacial outwash soils in the lower CRMW have high permeability and low available water capacity that typically result in droughty conditions for tree growth. Areas of Douglas-fir dieback due to laminated root rot (Phellinus weirii) are common in these soils in the lower watershed. The lower CRMW location in the foothills of the Cascade Mountains experiences periodic high winds that descend from the Cascade crest and cause crown abrasion, likely root stress, and substantial tree blown down. Douglas-fir stress and mortality caused by laminated root rot and blow down can result in increased Douglas-fir bark beetle populations that can then spread to live trees.

This combination of factors- drought stress, laminated root rot, windthrow, and bark beetles- makes forests on glacial outwash soils in the lower CRMW particularly sensitive to expected warmer temperatures resulting from global climate change. Greater moisture deficits resulting from warmer summer temperatures and reduced summer precipitation will make these forests highly vulnerable to disturbance from fire, insects, and pathogens, which in turn threaten the ability of the watershed to provide a clean water supply. Diversifying these forests will help to reduce their vulnerability to global climate change.

Bud-break phenology was observed on seedlings of the resilience planting trial in the Cedar River Municipal Watershed. Winter dormancy and timing of bud-break are important climate adaptations of tree species in temperate montane regions that experience cold winter temperatures. The study examined whether the timing of bud-break differs between species and seed sources for Douglas-fir. Greater plasticity in bud-break timing may indicate adaptive capacity to respond to changing spring temperatures associated with global climate change.

contact.organizationName: City of Seattle, Seattle Public Utilities

description.para: Planting trial design: This trial evaluated the success of planting several tree species and an Oregon seed zone Douglas-fir in a Douglas-fir dominated stand. Three 0.9 acre openings were created at the Foothills and Barneston planting sites. The openings are oriented North-South to maximize direct sunlight to the most seedlings. A total of 180 seedlings of each species or seed zone (Douglas-fir) were planted. The planting design consisted of two blocks of seven rows at Foothills and Barneston and two blocks of four rows at Thompson. Each row had 10 seedlings. Each of the four species other than Douglas-fir was represented by one row in each block. The two seed zones of Douglas-fir were only planted at Foothills and Thompson, where 15 seedlings of each seed zone were planted in each block (i.e. three rows of Douglas-fir). Each site had 60 seedlings of each species except Douglas-fir, and Foothills and Barneston had 90 seedlings of each Douglas-fir seed zone. The placement of each species in the block rows was randomized. Each Douglas-fir row was divided into two, with half the row planted with the Oregon and the other half with the Washington seed zone. The placement of the Oregon or Washington seed zone within a row was randomized, with the requirement that all three Douglas-fir rows in a block could not be of the same arrangement. The blocks were arranged north and south at Foothills and Barneston, along the long axis of the planting areas. At Thompson, the blocks were arranged east-west, which conformed better with the shape and size of the openings created by root rot. The nested-block design will allow analysis of variance among planting locations (Foothills, Barneston, and Thompson), including the effects of planting area (1, 2, and 3) and of block position (north, south). All seedlings except Douglas-fir were bare root or plug seedlings in March 2011 from Wabash Nursery in Enumclaw. Douglas-fir seedlings from Washington and Oregon were bare root seedlings. For more detail see attached pdf.

Bud-break was observed in the spring of 2015 and 2016 on terminal buds of seedlings installed in the 2011 planting trial. Bud-break stage description was adapted following Bailey and Harrington (2006) on seedlings of Pseudotsuga menziesii, Pinus monticola, Pinus contorta, ad Quercus garryana. Bud-break of Thuja plicata, which does not have buds with pre-formed growth, was determined by shoot elongation. Terminal shoots were marked 10-centimeters below the shoot terminus and total shoot length was measured. Seedlings were observed weekly beginning in April of 2015 and 2016 and sign of bud-break stage or shoot elongation was recorded together with Julian date. Once stage 2.0 of bud-break phenology was observed, the seedling was excluded from further observation.

project.title: Upland Forest Planting

personnel.organizationName: City of Seattle, Seattle Public Utilities

project.abstract: Restoration planting [C100025] Restoration planting will be done in selected upland secondgrowth stands where needed to diversify the plant community. The planting program will be designed to develop a diversity of trees and shrubs characteristic of naturally regenerated stands on similar sites and that will support a diversity of native wildlife species. Techniques are likely to include planting native forbs, shrubs, and trees, and spraying lichen fragments in the canopy. Hardwood development will be enhanced by recruiting species such as big leaf maple (Acer macrophyllum) and black cottonwood (Populus trichcocarpa) to diversify stand structure at lower elevations. The stands that will receive highest priority for restoration planting will be those that have plant diversity much lower than expected, based on site characteristics, and those with the greatest potential for beneficial results. Restoration planting is an experimental approach, and will be conducted within the adaptive management program described in Section 4.5.7. Projects will be monitored, and techniques will be changed in response to better understanding of how desired effects can be achieved. The program may be reduced or terminated if the City and Services determine that it is not effective in achieving its conservation objectives. Funding for restoration planting in upland areas will total $300,000. This includes $75,000 over the first 8 years, $75,000 over the second 8 years, and $150,000 over the remainder of the HCP term. The funding level is based on an estimated approximate average cost of $300 per acre for planting and maintenance. Based on that assumed cost per acre, the City expects that about 1,000 acres could be treated by restoration planting, about half of which would be treated in the first 16 years of the HCP term.

dataTable.entityDescription: Individual tree growth observations at time of planting in 2012 and in subsequent monitoring years 2013, 2014, 2015, and 2017. Includes tree ID, species, date of observation, vigor class, browse class, timing of bud break, and height. More information on methodology is included under methods and in attached Protocols for Monitoring Resilience Planting Trial pdf.

codeDefinition.definition: Leader dead only: the only tissue that has died is the leader

dataTable.entityDescription: Bud-break phenology was observed on seedlings of the resilience planting trial in the Cedar River Municipal Watershed. Winter dormancy and timing of bud-break are important climate adaptations of tree species in temperate montane regions that experience cold winter temperatures. The resilience planting trial was designed to test adaptation of different tree species to changing environmental conditions. This data captures if timing of bud-break differs between species and seed sources for Pseudotsuga menziesii. Greater plasticity in bud-break timing may indicate adaptive capacity to respond to changing spring temperatures associated with climate change. Bud-break was observed in the spring of 2015 and 2016 on terminal buds of seedlings installed in the 2011 planting trial. More information about methodology included under methods and in Phenology Study pdf.

attribute.attributeDefinition: budburst stage 0.5 Slightly swollen with some elongation, minor separation of terminal bud scales
budburst stage 1 Elongated, swollen bud with scale separation throughout the bud, lighter color overall
budburst stage 1.5 Extremely-swollen whitish buds, green tissue visible between scales near terminus
budburst stage 2 Fully-ruptured bud with new green foliage visible and protruding

otherEntity.entityDescription: Report including project plan from 2011, as-built report from 2012, initial results from 2013, and results update from 2017. Includes experiment rational, design, costs, monitoring and maintenance plans, and initial results. Written by David Chapin, Amy LaBarge, and Rolf Gersonde.

physical.objectName: CRMW Planting for Resilience Project Report_2017.pdf

otherEntity.entityDescription: Protocol for monitoring the resilience planting trail, author and date unknown.

physical.objectName: Protocols for Monitoring Resilience Planting Trial.pdf

otherEntity.entityDescription: Publication of results and analysis written by Rolf Gersonde in 2019. Includes abstract, introduction, methods, results, and discussion.

Phenology protocol and report for resilience planting trail in the Cedar River Municipal Watershed written by Rolf Gersonde in 2015-2016. Includes code descriptions for phenology data and median day of first observation of bud-break stage for species.

physical.objectName: Phenology Study of Resilience Planting Trial.pdf
